channel.title: NYT > Books
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Book Review: ‘Cheap Land Colorado,’ by Ted Conover
item.description: For his new book, the journalist Ted Conover joined a community of off-gridders in a desolate corner of the West, capturing lives full of anguish and contradiction.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Szalai
item.category: Cheap Land Colorado: Off-Gridders at America's Edge (Book)

item.title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
item.description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
item.category: The Third Reconstruction: America's Struggle for Racial Justice in the Twenty-First Century (Book)
Blood & Ink: The Scandalous Jazz Age Double Murder That Hooked America on True Crime (Book)

item.title: Bono By the Book Interview
item.description: “I got a copy of Edna O’ Brien’s ‘The Country Girls’ growing up, which hurried my puberty to a place where I thought differently about girls and women,” says the singer and frontman for U2, whose new memoir is “Surrender.” “I still do.”

item.title: Books on Democracy Under Threat
item.description: It’s among the world’s oldest forms of government, but it’s increasingly under threat. These books consider the sources and effects of an alarming global trend.
item.dc:creator: Richard Stengel
item.category: How Civil Wars Start: And How to Stop Them (Book)
The Road to Unfreedom: Russia, Europe, America (Book)
Twilight of Democracy: The Seductive Lure of the Authoritarian State (Book)
How Fascism Works: The Politics of Us and Them (Book)
The Next Civil War: Dispatches From the American Future (Book)
The Great Experiment: Why Diverse Democracies Fall Apart and How They Can Endure (Book)

item.title: 15 New Books Coming in November
item.description: A previously unpublished novel by Katherine Dunn, Matthew Perry’s harrowing account of yearslong addiction, the winner of the Booker Prize — and more.
item.dc:creator: Joumana Khatib
item.category: Requiem for the Massacre: A Black History on the Conflict, Hope, and Fallout of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre (Book)
Friends, Lovers and the Terrible Thing: A Memoir (Book)
We All Want Impossible Things: A Novel (Book)
Art Is Life: Icons and Iconoclasts, Visionaries and Vigilantes, and Flashes of Hope in the Night (Book)
The Light We Carry: Overcoming in Uncertain Times (Book)
item.media:credit: Hugo Yu for The New York Times

item.title: The Essential Philip K. Dick
item.description: A nuclear-strength imagination powered his stupendous output. Here’s where to start.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young
item.category: The Man in the High Castle (Book)
The Three Stigmata of Palmer Eldritch (Book)
Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep? (Book)
Flow My Tears, the Policeman Said (Book)
Selected Stories of Philip K Dick (Book)

item.title: The One Where Matthew Perry Writes an Addiction Memoir
item.description: In “Friends, Lovers and the Big Terrible Thing,” the actor gets serious about sobriety, mortality, colostomy bags and pickleball.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.category: Friends, Lovers and the Terrible Thing: A Memoir (Book)
item.media:credit: Michelle Groskopf for The New York Times
item.media:description: By the time he was 49, Matthew Perry writes in his new book, he had spent more than half of his life in treatment centers or sober living facilities.

item.title: How Colleen Hoover Rose to Rule the Best-Seller List
item.description: With legions of devoted fans and a knack for high-voltage emotional drama, Hoover has sold more than 20 million books. And she’s done it her way.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter
item.media:credit: Jake Dockins for The New York Times
item.media:description: Colleen Hoover at home in Texas this month. “She’s defying the laws of how the market works,” said an industry analyst.

item.title: Out Loud, Pumped Up and Bossed Around by the French
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Claire Keegan Harnesses the Power in Brevity
item.description: Keegan doesn’t write much, or publish often. But when she does, critics, readers and booksellers take notice.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter

item.title: Books That Teach Children About War Without Frightening Them
item.description: Four new picture books tackle the subject in sensitive, reassuring ways.
item.dc:creator: Eugene Yelchin
item.category: The Tower of Life: How Yaffa Eliach Rebuilt Her Town in Stories and Photographs (Book)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Book Review: ‘Martha Graham: When Dance Became Modern,’ by Neil Baldwin
item.description: The most revealing statements in a new biography come from the dancers who gave their lives and bodies to her experiments.
item.dc:creator: Brian Seibert
item.category: Martha Graham: When Dance Became Modern: A Life (Book)
item.media:description: Martha Graham in “Clytemnestra,” 1960. Agnes de Mille said Graham was “among the last of the sacrificial females.”

item.title: Katherine Duncan-Jones, Who Cast Shakespeare as a Boor, Dies at 81
item.description: A fearless scholar of English literature, she argued in books and interviews that the revered playwright was a narcissist, misogynist and social climber.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Rebecca Godfrey, 54, Dies; Author Found Humanity in Teenage Violence
item.description: She drew praise for the precision and compassion of “Under the Bridge,” her account of the beating and murder of a 14-year-old girl.
item.dc:creator: Penelope Green
item.category: Under the Bridge: The True Story of the Murder of Reena Virk (Book)

item.title: Steps in the Left Direction
item.description: Playbooks for political change from Robert Kuttner and Eric Holder, and a historian’s warning about the heart of the resistance.
item.dc:creator: James Goodman
item.category: Going Big: FDR's Legacy, Biden's New Deal, and the Struggle to Save Democracy (Book)
Why White Liberals Fail: Race and Southern Politics from FDR to Trump (Book)
Our Unfinished March: The Violent Past and Imperiled Future of the Vote -- A History, A Crisis, A Plan (Book)

item.title: ‘Design Mom’ Gabrielle Blair Pivots to Politics
item.description: After 16 years of making a name for herself as a blogger and home decor expert, Design Mom has written her manifesto — about reproductive health.
item.dc:creator: Kase Wickman
item.media:credit: Matthew Avignone for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gabrielle Blair, 48, also known as Design Mom, sits in her study at home in Argentan, France. Her family has been restoring the 17th century house since 2019.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party,’ by Stephen Shames and Ericka Huggins
item.description: From schools to free food and health care, the group’s majority female membership carried out life-sustaining, grass-roots programs that went far beyond politics.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Christensen
item.category: Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party (Book)

item.title: Book Review: “We All Want Impossible Things,” by Catherine Newman
item.description: In her novel “We All Want Impossible Things,” Catherine Newman achieves the near-impossible: a story about death, with humor.
item.dc:creator: Julie Klam
item.category: We All Want Impossible Things: A Novel (Book)

item.title: For ‘Fleishman Is in Trouble,’ Claire Danes and Jesse Eisenberg Say I Do
item.description: The actors share a doomed union in this new FX series. In a joint interview, they discuss their own marriages and how it felt to depict such a contentious one.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Thea Traff for The New York Times
item.media:description: In “Fleishman Is in Trouble,” Claire Danes and Jesse Eisenberg play two halves of a splintered couple.

item.title: Adaptations of ‘Anne of Green Gables’ Are Proliferating
item.description: Suddenly, remakes and adaptations of L.M. Montgomery’s “Anne of Green Gables” series are proliferating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Hong
item.category: Anne: An Adaptation of 'Anne of Green Gables' (Sort Of) (Book)
item.media:credit: M. A. and W. A. J. Claus

item.title: Ukrainians Turn to Diaries for Solace, and to Share Life in Wartime
item.description: Writers have long used diaries to make sense of life. Now, diaries can be shared in real time, helping shape public perception of events as they unfold — including war.
item.dc:creator: Nina Siegal
item.media:description: A portrait of a volunteer of Kyiv’s Zoo Patrol, by Mila Teshaieva. Teshaieva went from Berlin to Kyiv, her hometown, when the war started, and recorded her impressions in diary entries and photos.

item.title: Hannah Pick-Goslar, a Presence in Anne Frank’s Diary, Dies at 93
item.description: The two young women knew each other from kindergarten until their final encounter, on opposite sides of a barbed-wire fence in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir
item.media:credit: Anne Frank Fonds - Basel via Getty Images

item.title: Philip Hiat, Rabbi Who Forged Bonds With Other Faiths, Dies at 95
item.description: His bridge-building efforts notably included a book and traveling exhibition of Jewish manuscripts from the Vatican’s archives.
item.dc:creator: Ed Shanahan
item.category: Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion
item.media:credit: Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Rabbi Philip Hiat, left, and others in 1981 examining Torah scrolls salvaged from Polish synagogues that were destroyed during the Nazi occupation.

item.title: Her Plan for Putting the World Back Together? Trees.
item.description: Diana Beresford-Kroeger’s connection to trees stems from an ancient Irish prophecy she heard in childhood. And she thinks trees are crucial in addressing climate change.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: In ‘Dangerous Liaisons,’ Alice Englert and Nicholas Denton Play the Game
item.description: In a decadent new Starz drama, the two actors play young versions of literature’s most poisoned and poisonous power couple.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Soloski
item.media:credit: Sabrina Santiago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Denton and Alice Englert play Pascal, a young mapmaker, and Camille, a sex worker, before they become the Vicomte de Valmont and Marquise de Merteuil.

item.title: Brigitte Giraud Wins Goncourt Prize With Tragic Novel of Loss
item.description: The prestigious French literary award went to “Living Fast,” or “Vivre Vite,” which explores the causes of an accident that killed the author’s partner.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Julien De Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Brigitte Giraud in Paris in October. Previous Goncourt winners include Marcel Proust, Simone de Beauvoir and Marguerite Duras.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Shanda,’ by Letty Cottin Pogrebin; ‘A Girlhood,’ by Carolyn Hays; ‘The Family Outing,’ by Jessi Hempel
item.description: From lost children to sexual and gender identity, moral crises abound.
item.dc:creator: Jake Nevins
item.category: Shanda: A Memoir of Shame and Secrecy (Book)
A Girlhood: Letter to My Transgender Daughter (Book)

item.title: Sizzling, Sparking, White-Hot Romance Novels
item.description: Nothing is more satisfying than the emotional combustion of characters who were meant to be together.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Waite

item.title: Poem: Metaphor of the Floating Life
item.description: Images articulate the feelings of a “divided self” and a sense of being everywhere and nowhere at once.
item.dc:creator: Song Lin and Victoria Chang

item.title: Review: ‘The Year of Magical Thinking’ Gets Joan Didion’s Intention Just Right
item.description: A play based on the writer’s memoir about the death of her husband, in its first New York revival, goes small to powerful effect.
item.dc:creator: Laura Collins-Hughes

item.title: How Her Ancestors Reignited Her Return to Theater
item.description: Quiara Alegría Hudes is back with a new work, an Off Broadway production of “My Broken Language,” adapted from her 2021 memoir.
item.dc:creator: Jose Solís
item.media:credit: Molly Matalon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Quiara Alegría Hudes on the set of her new play, “My Broken Language,” at Signature Theater in Manhattan.

item.title: Book Review: ‘It’s Not TV,’ by Felix Gillette and John Koblin
item.description: A new history of the entertainment company traces its origins in a culture of male license, misogyny — and violence.
item.dc:creator: Sam Adler-Bell
item.media:description: James Gandolfini as Tony Soprano, 1999.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Magic To Do,' by Elysa Gardner
item.description: Elysa Gardner’s “Magic to Do” goes backstage at Bob Fosse and Stephen Schwartz’s 1972 musical about a lost prince.
item.dc:creator: Marshall Heyman

item.title: Book Review: ‘Shuna’s Journey,’ by Hayao Miyazaki
item.description: First published in Japan in 1983, this picture book from the fabled animator is eerie, enchanting and surpassingly strange.
item.dc:creator: Susan Napier

item.title: Newly Published, From Egotistical Artists to Corporate Control
item.description: A selection of recently published books.

item.title: A Merger Between Penguin Random House and Simon & Schuster Was Blocked, but Brought the Industry Little Clarity
item.description: The uncertainty comes at a time when publishing is facing slumping sales after a pandemic boom, and fears of recession.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter

item.title: Book Review: ‘Vigilance,’ by Andrew K. Diemer
item.description: Andrew Diemer’s “Vigilance” gives a freedom fighter his due.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Clinton
item.category: Vigilance: The Life of William Still, Father of the Underground Railroad (Book)
item.media:credit: Charles L. Blockson Afro-American Collection, Temple University
item.media:description: William Still, circa 1870

item.title: Julie Powell, Food Writer Known for ‘Julie & Julia,’ Dies at 49
item.description: She attempted to cook every recipe in a classic Julia Child cookbook and documented the effort in a popular blog that became a best-selling book and a hit movie.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson and Julia Moskin

item.title: Book Review: ‘Dr. No,’ by Percival Everett
item.description: “Dr. No,” which borrows its name from an early James Bond story, features a math professor who’s recruited by a supervillain.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Book Review: ‘Case Study,’ by Graeme Macrae Burnet
item.description: “Case Study,” by Graeme Macrae Burnet, is a novel of found documents detailing troubled lives and shifting identities.
item.dc:creator: Christian Lorentzen
item.media:credit: Sam Mellish/In Pictures via Getty Images
item.media:description: Primrose Hill, London, where the novel “Case Study” is set.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Requiem for the Massacre,’ by RJ Young
item.description: RJ Young’s “Requiem for the Massacre” is more coming-of-age story than reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Martha Southgate
item.category: Requiem for the Massacre: A Black History on the Conflict, Hope, and Fallout of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre (Book)
item.media:credit: Department of Special Collections, McFarlin Library, The University of Tulsa, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A group of Black men are marched down Tulsa’s Main Street on June 1, 1921.

item.title: Review: ‘The Island of Extraordinary Captives,’ by Simon Parkin
item.description: In Simon Parkin’s riveting account, a shameful chapter in British history is also a testament to creativity and hope.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Nicolson
item.media:description: A group of refugees, including future Hutchinson inmate Peter Fleischmann, shortly after disembarking the Kindertransport ferry, 1938.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Art Is Life,’ by Jerry Saltz
item.description: “Art Is Life” collects the art critic’s essays, reviews, interviews and more from the past two decades.
item.dc:creator: Zoë Lescaze
item.category: Art Is Life: Icons and Iconoclasts, Visionaries and Vigilantes, and Flashes of Hope in the Night (Book)
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: ‘Saha,’ by Cho Nam-Joo
item.description: In her new novel, “Saha,” Cho Nam-Joo follows a group of outcasts to examine the strict enforcement of social hierarchies.
item.dc:creator: Lincoln Michel

item.title: Book Review: ‘Trespasses,’ by Louise Kennedy
item.description: Louise Kennedy’s debut novel, “Trespasses,” considers the relationship of a Catholic woman and a Protestant man.
item.dc:creator: J. Courtney Sullivan

item.title: Essay: ‘Toad,’ by Katherine Dunn
item.description: The posthumous publication of a new novel, six years after Dunn’s death, is a chance to celebrate the bawdy originality of the author of the cult hit “Geek Love.”
item.dc:creator: Adrienne Raphel

item.title: Book Review: “Before You Knew My Name,” by Jacqueline Bublitz
item.description: Jacqueline Bublitz’s debut, “Before You Knew My Name,” follows the parallel tracks of two women in New York City — one vital and vibrant, the other not so much.
item.dc:creator: Flynn Berry

item.title: Penguin Random House’s Bid to Acquire Simon & Schuster Blocked by Judge
item.description: The government’s case blocked the merger of two of the United States’ largest publishers and reflected a more aggressive approach to curbing consolidation. It was closely watched by the publishing industry.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: Penguin Random House’s 100 or so imprints publish more than 2,000 titles a year. The merger would have added another 50 imprints from Simon & Schuster.

item.title: Book Review: ‘Mr. B,’ by Jennifer Homans
item.description: “Mr. B,” by Jennifer Homans, explores the life of the Russian-born choreographer, as well as the beauty and pains of his art.
item.dc:creator: Dwight Garner
item.media:description: The choreographer George Balanchine backstage with one of his dancers in 1972.

item.title: Louise Kennedy’s Debut Novel Taps Into Her Childhood Amid the Troubles
item.description: The book, “Trespasses,” captures the texture of life in Northern Ireland — details, objects and images that carry “incredible emotional weight.”
item.dc:creator: Tobias Grey
item.media:credit: Ellius Grace for The New York Times
item.media:description: Louise Kennedy in Sligo, Ireland. Her family moved to Ireland to escape violence, including bombing attempts of her grandfather’s pub, in Northern Ireland. The experiences would later inform her writing.

item.title: Book Review: ‘A Spectre, Haunting: On the Communist Manifesto,’ by China Miéville
item.description: In “A Spectre, Haunting,” the British fantasy writer and political activist China Miéville makes the case for why Marx and Engels’s famous pamphlet remains vital today.
item.dc:creator: Cory Doctorow

item.title: Book Review: “Gilded Mountain,” Kate Manning
item.description: In “Gilded Mountain,” Kate Manning explores the bedrock of the labor movement through the experience of one family.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan

item.title: Msgr. John Meier, Who Searched for ‘Historical Jesus,’ Dies at 80
item.description: For more than three decades, he worked on his multivolume series, “A Marginal Jew,” drawing praise from Pope Benedict XVI.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Thomas Cahill, Popular Writer of Ireland’s History, Dies at 82
item.description: His book “How the Irish Saved Civilization” became a best seller and helped open the door to a new appreciation of that country’s culture.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen

item.title: Ralph Macchio siempre será el ‘Karate Kid’ y al fin está en paz con eso
item.description: En sus nuevas memorias, la estrella de los 80 se reconcilia con el papel que lo ha devuelto a las pantallas gracias a ‘Cobra Kai’.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Cannariato
item.media:credit: Tonje Thilesen para The New York Times
item.media:description: A sus 60 años, Ralph Macchio, de apariencia siempre juvenil, ha escrito unas memorias sobre cómo Karate Kid le cambió la vida.

item.title: A Factual Account of Truman Capote, Notorious Embroiderer of Truth
item.description: In “Deliberate Cruelty,” Roseanne Montillo delves into a grisly mystery involving one of the writer’s many nemeses.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Jacobs
item.category: Deliberate Cruelty: Truman Capote, the Millionaire's Wife, and the Murder of the Century (Book)

item.title: Teaching Children About Climate Change
item.description: Two new picture books and a novel for young readers place children at the center of environmental calamity.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.category: The Coquies Still Sing: A Story of Home, Hope, and Rebuilding (Book)
Dear Wild Child: You Carry Your Home Inside You (Book)
item.media:description: From “The Coquíes Still Sing.”
